text: Sharyn BNN hi everyone
Anthony Fantino here Internet's busiest
music nerd and it's time for an album
review Sharon Van Etten
Sharon Van Etten is a Brooklyn
singer-songwriter who I've been
listening to ever since she made her
little first handmade demos although I
haven't totally been head over heels
with everything that she's done in the
past from the sort of rough around the
edges because I was in love which is an
album kind of based on those initial
demos to the criminally short album epic
every time I listen to one of her
releases I always think yeah this is
good but there's just this kind of
potential that's not being fully
realized I guess but there are things
that are already inherently great about
Sharon that kind of keep me coming back
to her releases again and again and then
like Sharon's songwriting which always
has some pretty great lyrics and her
voice which is always just so raw and a
motive she's got a really mature and and
womanly voice in no sense is it light or
girly or flimsy and that helps a lot
when Sharon is trying to transmit the
emotions behind these post breakup songs
or at least they feel like post breakup
songs to me this album kind of feels
like the act of unpacking emotional
baggage leftover after you've broken up
with somebody and you're just kind of
unpacking box after box after box
sifting through things seeing what's
worth salvaging what needs to be thrown
away ASAP and what you just can't let go
of no matter how much you want to you
kind of get these really vague memories
all throughout this album of turning
points in relationships with this person
or people like on the song give out
where Sharon is saying to a particular
person and saying that you're the reason
I
move to the city you're the reason I'll
leave or on the song serpents where
Charon is singing about kind of this
inevitable change that's coming and it's
a change that's gonna bring thinking
thinking things closer to the end and I
guess she's trying to come to terms with
that and the track all I can seems to be
singing about just just personal flaws
and mistakes and and accepting that as
well it's in a way that's sort of
assuring for the listener too because I
feel like she's just singing directly at
me and she's just trying to do
everything in her power to get me to
understand this there's a lot of
emotional strength on this LP but there
are spots of weakness to on here like on
the track I'm wrong it seems like
Sharon's trying to grab validation from
this broken relationship by singing to
this person asking if if she was worth
all the miles he put on his car I guess
to keep the relationship going the
relationship is over but it was still
good right it wasn't just a waste of
time right there's just a range of
feelings and stories focusing on this
dying love and even though that's not a
novel concept in music and songwriting
Sheeran is just so passionate and so
good a singer that I just want to hear
her side of the story and that passion
again for me comes through the great
singing and some really good vocal
melodies too on the song Leonard she has
this vocal melody that's constantly
ascending and descending and in this
really catchy way she's also got a load
of very close vocal harmonies on this LP
too they have kind of a first aid kit
quality to them especially on the track
serpents which is sung really loudly and
intensely and there are moments on here
where she's singing and her voice just
seems very spotlighted very alone and
kind of sweet and understated like on
the track joke or Ally if it wasn't
already a parent just Sharon's voice her
melodies her lyrics and the chords that
she uses to build her songs to me are
the most interesting thing has
going for it so for me the songs
feel the best on this album are the
tracks that are either the simplest or
just kind of have the the least bells
and whistles and showcase those
strengths like the track give out which
is pretty much just acoustic guitar and
voice but it's backed up by some really
light electric guitar leads that feel
pretty atmospheric and dramatic and
these heavy but but sparse drums just
really spacious leaving tons of room for
the emotion of the track the
instrumentation does get harder and
louder on this LP too though like on the
track serpents which has this very
driving drumbeat the guitars get heavier
too but it's not a busy song the musics
volume is just rising to match the
intensity of Sharon's songwriting on
that track it's on the song Leonard that
I think the instrumentation becomes a
little too much I guess I do love that
track it's one of my favorites on the
album and the instrumentation does kind
of feel lush and plentiful between what
sounds kind of like an accordion or a
pump organ a piano but the performance
just kind of feels really predictable it
feels like the instrumentation is
supposed to be there a lot like you're
supposed to do your homework and as a
result they just kind of play what it
sounds like they're supposed to play the
song kind of skips along like like it
was a Beirut tune or something and and
speaking of Beirut Zac Condon of Beirut
is actually on the eighth track here we
are fine singing but honestly that song
does kind of add up to my least-favorite
on here I just feel like Zac's erratic
vibrato works much better alone I just
don't really dig it all that much mixed
with with a Sharon Van Etten's song and
her voice too
but there are actually quite a few other
notable indie musicians featured on this
LP Julianne Barwick is on here Jen
wasner from the van Y oak as well as
Matt Barrack from The Walkmen
and Aaron Dessner from the National is
on here as well he actually owns the
studio that this album was recorded in
the personality and the songs and the
stories are are there you know I just
feel like some of these songs have
quirks about them they're just kind of
turned me off
like the opening track which is kind of
loud but just so short and does not
leave the impact on me the gripping
impact that I feel like a first track
should and on the track in line the
vocal melody kind of wanders in a way
that doesn't really deliver a melody to
me that that kind of sticks with me you
know I prefer the tracks on here where
the vocals just feel more precise I just
think the last several tracks on this LP
are pretty awesome though the track
asked follows that simpler and more
confessional style of songwriting that
other tracks succeed with on this album
plus I love how intense and loud that
track gets as it kind of progresses
starts off very soft but the
instrumentation subtly introduces itself
as it moves along just getting more and
more in the last two tracks Joker Ally
and I'm wrong feature Sheeran singing
over this kind of jeroni instrumentation
it's a trick she's done before but she's
brought it up to another level on this
LP the track I'm wrong feels really kind
of huge kind of epic with some booming
drums towards its end some guitar hums
kind of rising in the background they
have a little bit of bite to them that
track for me is kind of like watching an
explosion in slow motion this time
around I feel like Sharon is doing way
more instrumentally and production wise
then she did with epic more instruments
more musical guests sometimes I feel
like they complement her songs sometimes
I feel like they don't other times I
could just kind of take it or leave it I
just kind of end up with a group of
tracks on here that kind of pale in
comparison to others by a large degree
maybe maybe but whatever because like
this album acknowledges change it's
inevitable it's gonna happen it's got to
happen just roll with the punches I did
end up liking this album a lot though
feeling kind of a decent too strong 7 on
this thing what do you guys think about
it do you love it do you hate it why and
what should I
review next anthony Fantana
Sharon man Eden forever
[Music]
